My experience: I've lived most of my life with my natural cycle, I'm in my mid 40s. But I have tried the pill, although I started using it later than many women. I first got the combined pill when I was 26, because that's when I became sexually active. The pill was called Jeanine and I don't remember having any side effects, but a lot was happening in my life so I might not have paid attention. A year later I moved to the UK, and I told my GP the name of the pill I had been on, assuming that he would either prescribe the same or the most similar pill. I got Microgynon that soon gave me painful breasts, weight gain and mood swings. The side effects were so bad, I decided to take a break, and felt so much better, that I never wanted to use any hormones again. Also years later I realised the GP never told me that Microgynon contained an older than Jeanine generation of progestogen. The progestogen in Microgynon is now PROVEN to increase the risk of breast cancer. Fast forward two decades, my periods became heavier and more frequent, and I started suffering from anemia. I have also been diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. My GP recommended the desogestrel POP. I was hesitant, but decided to give it a try. Unfortunately it soon gave me awful mood swings. Not normal mood fluctuations, but weird sudden changes. I was feeling good most of the time, better than without the pill, but for the smallest reasons I would get a sudden mood drop, so bad, that I felt violently suicidal. I'm almost 45, I know myself, I've been through good and bad times, including a tragedy in my family, including grief, and I have never experienced anything like I did on desogestrel. So I stopped using it. I also started reading a lot about hormones, and discovered that the pill does not regulate anything, but switches off your own hormones to replace them with artificial substitutes, that are similar to hormones but don't do everything that hormones do. Nobody knows what the long term consequences of living without your natural hormones are. The pill's safety is largely based on the fact that it's "well tolerated" by most users. But is it? I now rely on private hormone tests and herbal treatment for regulation of hormones.

I asked to be put on the pill at 16 when I started seeing my first boyfriend. It seemed like it was what everyone else was doing so I thought it would probably be right for me. When I asked doctors about this they completely dismissed it so I had to just make the decision to come off it without consulting a medical professional. Because the pill had been so difficult for me I had a copper coil fitted as I wanted a solution that was hormone free. I had heard horror stories from friends about the pain getting it inserted so I did my research and was told to take paracetamol before my appointment. Even with this pain relief (I wasn't offered anything like in this documentary) the insertion was very painful and made me scared to have it removed. Immediately after insertion for around a week I was cramping and bleeding. I was told that the coil normally takes a month to settle however mine never did and I experienced a dull ache in my uterus constantly. When my period came the pain was so excruciating I would pass out. I couldn't even have sex (which is the whole point of having contraception) because it was consistently painful. I told medical professionals about this several times and I kept being told to wait and see if it settled - this was even suggested at an appointment I had a year after having it fitted. I kept having to advocate for myself and all anyone would offer me was pain relief for my painful periods that I didn't have before having the coil fitted. My body felt completely out of my control and I would cry all of the time because of the pain I was being forced to experience due to doctors and nurses not believing me that it was "bad enough" to warrant their time. I asked to have an ultrasound several times to check the coil was in the correct position and was dismissed consistently. I was finally admitted for this after I cried to a nurse at a walk in clinic that I had already visited 3 different times to try and get the problem resolved. Finally 2 months later I had my ultrasound and they found nothing wrong. I was absolutely adamant that I needed to have the coil removed after hearing that this was "supposed" to be how it felt because I couldn't live my life in pain anymore. I had my routine smear test and tried to speak to the nurse briefly about having my coil removed in my appointment. She informed me that she wouldn't remove the coil I had unless I wanted to get pregnant. When I said that I did not want to get pregnant she said she wouldn't book me in for an appointment to get the coil removed and that I would probably want children soon so I should just wait to have it removed then (I don't and it was none of her business). I was absolutely appalled at this appointment and felt so angry that a foreign object that sterilised and hurt me was being kept in my body without my consent unless I met the specific non medically based opinions of a nurse. Then the pandemic hit so I had another year with this coil in. I eventually was able to book an appointment with a different nurse to get the coil removed. I was really nervous the day I was getting it out and I expected to be in so much pain. The nurse was really kind and talked me through the whole process. After she had put the speculum in I didn't even feel it being taken out. She said it was done and I felt instant relief. About a day later the dull ache finally went away after years of me being in pain. I knew it was wrong from the beginning and I should have been taken seriously and had it taken out immediately. My periods are sill much much heavier than before I ever had the coil and knowing that I will have to live with that for the rest of my life when it could have so easily been avoided makes me feel so sad and angry every month. I understand why documentaries like this promote the coil because its the exact same reasons I had it put in but I really think people who have had coils fitted are not taken seriously when they talk about their pain. Having a uterus does not mean we should experience pain and have out bodily autonomy taken away from us. We all deserve better.
